titleSet.title: Map of India And Jawaharlal Nehru

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Map of India

description-en: In this poster from the Empire Calender Manufacturing Co. Jawaharlal Nehru is depicted atop a map showing India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Burma and Pakistan. On top of Kashmir, an Indian flag can be seen. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The presence of the Indian national tricolor suggests that this is a map of independent India, separated from the territories colored deep green. We have to look hard, though, to find the word “Pakistan” inscribed across the green mass to the west, while the eastern section of the new nation is still inscribed with the word Bengal across it. Yet a clearly delineated green line separates the new nations of Pakistan and India as announced by Radcliffe’s Boundary Award in August 1947. The map in this print possibly alludes to a time in the months immediately following partition and independence when princely states (such as Baluchistan, Khairpur or Bahawalpur) had yet to formally accede to Pakistan, and Kashmir was still independent. Bahawalpur and Khairpur joined Pakistan in October 1947, the various Baluchi states (Makran, Kharan, Las Bela and Kalat) in early 1948 (Wilcox, Wayne. 1963. Pakistan: The Consolidation of a Nation. New York: Columbia University Press, pp. 68-85). The map of India shown in this print also points to a time before the numerous princely states had been merged with each other to form larger entities that eventually were “integrated” into the new Republic. Thus, for instance, we do not see Saurastra (created in January 1948), P.E.P.S.U. (formed in July 1948), or Madhya Bharat (founded in April 1948), and Rajasthan still appears under the name of “Rajputana” (only progressively abandoned from March 1948). (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The position of the Indian flag on top of Kashmir could be a symbol for the tenure of India concerning the state of Kashmir, that is still depicted as independent on this map. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Such prints may not be as benign as they look on first appearances: This one shows the newly-delineated map of India in the company of Jawaharlal Nehru who looks directly out at us with a slightly weary look. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The most striking aspect of both prints possibly is the Indian tricolor flying triumphantly over the nation’s territory, the staff bearing it firmly planted on Kashmir. By late 1947, although the erstwhile princely state of Kashmir had agreed in an emergency maneuver to join India (through the strategic interventions and overtures primarily of Nehru), parts of its western territory had been claimed by neighbouring Pakistan after the first of the many wars and skirmishes had ended in the stalemate that endures more or less to this day. Since that time, official maps of India subsume the entirety of Kashmir, disavowing the Line of Control (LOC), the de facto border that separates Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir from Pakistan-administered Azad Kashmir and the Northern Areas. On the eastern side as well, Aksai Chin remains another no-man’s land, claimed since the 1950s by both India and China, a claim over which they went to war in 1962: here as well, a so-called Line of Actual Control constitutes the de facto border which state cartography ignores. International maps showing otherwise are stamped with the statuary comment, “The external boundaries of India as depicted on this map are neither correct nor authentic.” (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
